a b s t r a c t
This article presents a short review of the knowledge concerning carbon nano-onions, also known as onion-like carbon or multi-layered fullerenes. Currently, these nanostructures are some of the most fascinating carbon forms. We can only find approximately 2000 articles under the entry of ‘‘carbon onion” in theWeb of Science. Surprisingly, there have been 40,000 citations since their discovery, and the interest in these nanostructures is still growing. In the last three years, 5000 citations per year have been reported. This means that researchers have noted the unusual nature of these carbon nanostructures. In this article, we review the most important literature reports in this area, which in a condensed way, present these nanostructures, their production methods, their unusual physical and chemical properties and their potential uses.

sections.heading: 1. Introduction
sections.text:
Recently, materials chemistry has been one of most intensively developing fields of science. It mainly involves the synthesis of new materials or the modification of their surfaces so that new properties can allow for their practical application. Much attention has been devoted to nanoparticles, which can form bigger micro- and
macromolecular systems. Since the discovery of fullerenes in 1992 [1], carbon nanoparticles have been quite commonly used in such systems. Recently, larger morphological variations of fullerene-like all-carbon nanostructures (CNs) have received enormous attention. Carbon nano-onions (CNOs) are a member of the fullerene family, and they consist of quasi-spherical- and polyhedralshaped graphitic layers close to one another. The distance between the graphitic layers is 0.335 nm, and it is approximately equal to the distance between two graphitic planes (0.334 nm) [2]. The

CxðnÞ ¼ C60 n2 ð1Þ where n is the subsequent number of the corresponding layer; x(n) defines the number of carbon atoms comprising the layer [3,4]. The structure of CNOs contains hexagonal and pentagonal rings with carbon atoms located at the vertices forming two single bonds and one double bond with neighbouring carbon atoms with delocalized p-electrons across the molecule [5,6]. Graphitic layers in the structure of this nanomaterial consist of a significant number of defects and holes [7]. The holes can be filled in a variety of ways
with heptagonal and pentagonal carbon rings, creating amorphous or crystalline quasi-spherical onions [8]. However, CNOs discovered by Sumio Iijima in 1980 [9], did not garner as much interest as carbon nanotubes (CNTs) discovered at the same time. It is surprising, but the interest in them dates back to the beginning of 2000, modifications of these nanostructures began to be addressed.

sections.heading: 2. Production, structures and physical properties of the onionlike structures
sections.text:
Although various methods have been published for the synthesis of CNOs, the main synthetic methods have been thermal
annealing of ultradispersed nanodiamonds (NDs) [10], arc-discharge between two electrodes submerged in water [11,12,13], pyrolysis [14], ion implantation [15], chemical vapour deposition [16], or electron-beam irradiation [17]. Depending on the preparation method of the onion-like structures, different types of nanostructures can be achieved with varying sizes (‘‘big” [13,18] and ‘‘small” [10,19]), shapes (spherical [19,20,18] [21] and polyhedral [20,19]), and types of cores (dense [13,19,18] and hollow [20,21,7]) (Fig. 1 and Table 1).
Fig. 1 presents images obtained with high-resolution transmission electron microscopy (HRTEM) representing the different types of onion-like carbon nanostructures. The dimensions of the nanostructures fluctuate within the range of 2 and 200 nm (Table 1). Small amounts of spherical and polyhedral CNOs with diameters ranging from 8 to 15 nm were created in vacuum (10 6 Torr) [9]. Amorphous carbon layers were deposited on the surface of carbon rods and nanoparticles consisting of concentric multi-shells inside an amorphous carbon film. Iijima observed that the distance between the layers is approximately 3.44 Å, and the angles between graphitic planes is approximately 120 ± 20 [9]. About a decade later in 1992, Daniel Ugarte examined the formation of CNOs at 300-kV HRTEM by irradiating a carbon soot material and observing the formation of quasi-spherical onion-like particles with diameters ranging from 6 to 47 nm that were composed of concentric graphitic shells ( 70 shells) [22].
Large-scale production (gram quantities) of CNOs was realized through a method proposed by Kuznetsov et al. [10]. The method is based on annealing of nanodiamond (ND) particles (average diameter of 5 nm) at high temperatures in an inert atmosphere under high vacuum (Fig. 1a). The diameter of the formed CNOs is analogous to the diameter of the used NDs (Fig. 1b). The transformation of NDs to CNOs is a multistep process and is schematically presented in Fig. 2 [24]. The distance between the diamond planes in bulk diamond is 0.205 nm [25]. Thermal annealing of NDs at temperatures from 700 to 800 C leads to the removal of oxygencontaining groups and the emergence of CO and CO2 gases [26]. At temperatures between 1100 and 1300 C the outer graphene layers become more graphitic with a lower defect density [24]. Further annealing of NDs up to 1800 C leads to the formation of small particles with 6–8 graphitic shells and diameters of 5– 6 nm, and these particles are frequently called ‘‘small” CNOs. The interlayer distance is close to 0.35 nm, i.e., typical for bulk graphite (d002=0.334 nm) [10]. Thermal annealing of NDs up to 1900 C leads to the formation of polyhedral nanostructures (Fig. 1c) [19]. Currently, the method for the production of CNOs from the annealing of NDs is one of the most economical methods of synthesis for spherical CNOs and has potential for industrial applications, as the onion yield is close to 100% (the amount of non-carbon material is typically in the range of 1–2 wt) [24]. Synthesis of CNOs with few layers is highly desired to increase the ability to modify them using
chemical reactions, since this type of CNO has greater surface curvature and strain energy, which leads to higher chemical reactivity [27,28].
Another method for the preparation of CNOs was proposed by N. Sano, which is based on an arc-discharge (voltage was 16 V and current was 30 A) between two graphite electrodes submerged in water [13]. This method resulted in the creation of hollow-core, bigger onion-like nanostructures with 20–30 graphene layers with particle diameters between 15 and 25 nm (Fig. 1d) [29]. The next popular method is ion implantation of carbon ions into copper [30,31,32] or silver substrates [33,34,35]. Depending on the implantation parameters (temperature, substrate concentration, implanted dose, and grain size of substrate), the created CNOs can have different size distributions, homogeneities and microstructures (defects, spherical shape, etc.). Higher temperatures lead to the formation of a more ideal structure of the carbon nanoparticles [36]. The carbon nanostructures obtained from a low implanted dose have more defective structures with small sizes (2–5 nm) [37,38].
Chemical vapour deposition was also considered as a viable method of the production of CNOs [16,39]. This process was performed in the presence of a metal catalyst, high temperature and high pressure. From this method, pristine (undoped) spherical nanoparticles with diameters between 5 and 50 nm were obtained in large quantities. Primarily effective and low-cost method is the pyrolysis of propane (diameter between 10 and 25 nm) [40] or plastic wastes (polyethylene, styrene, or ethylene terephthalate) (diameter between 50 and 70 nm) [41]. The product requires additional purification in view of the presence of by-products. There are many other methods for the production of CNOs, including catalyst-free thermolysis using sodium azide (NaN3) and hexachlorobenzene (C6Cl6) [42], laser ablation [43], solid-state carbonization of phenolic resin [44], halogen gas treatment [45], high-energy ball milling [46] and heavy shock compression [47].
The size, number of layers, physical and chemical properties of CNOs depend on the synthetic conditions of their preparation. Due to the advantages of ND-derived CNOs, i.e., small size, spherical shape, high reactivity, and high yield during synthesis, a great interest in these materials was created among scientists in the last 10 years. Annealing NDs at temperatures between 800–2100 C in vacuum results in the formation of CNOs with the different graphene-like structures (spherical, polyhedral or ellipsoidal nanoparticles) that were demonstrated by experimental [49,50] and theoretical [51] evidence. There is a strong connection between the synthetic conditions and the structural properties of the
Fig. 3. (a) Raman spectra of ND powders before and after annealing [48] and (b) X-ray atmosphere [24]. Adapted with permission from Refs. [48,24]. Copyright 2017 Royal So
obtained CNOs [52]. The transformation of NDs to CNOs at high temperatures has been investigated in argon [53,49,54,55,56,57], helium [29] and hydrogen [58] atmospheres. Annealing the ND powder in an argon atmosphere leads to graphitization, while annealing in an oxygen atmosphere leads to the oxidation of these nanostructures at the temperatures 500 C. Increasing the annealing temperature for NDs under an argon atmosphere leads to an increase of the degree of graphitization and a decrease of the size of the ND particles. The effect of a hydrogen environment under atmospheric pressure on the structure of the formed CNOs was also investigated [58]. The synthesis was performed in a CO2 atmosphere, called the ‘‘dry” technique, and using an aqueous environment, called the ‘‘wet” technique. From these methods, onion-like structures were formed with a partial content of the diamond (sp3) phase.
In the case of the synthesis of CNOs from ND structures, sp2 weight fractions, shapes, densities, conductivities, specific surface areas, and average pore sizes have been changed. Increasing the annealing temperature leads to an increase in the degree of sp2 carbon ordering from 0.39 (temperature of approximately 1100 C) to 1 (temperature of approximately 1900 C) [59]. The annealing of NDs at temperatures between 1300 and 1800 C leads to the formation of spherical CNOs, whereas further heating of NDs over 1900 C leads to formation of polyhedral nanoparticles [60]. Increasing the annealing temperature results in a decrease of the density from 3.07 ± 0.02 to 2.03 ± 0.02 g (cm3) 1 [61]. It is caused by a transformation of the diamond core to graphitic layers. Increasing the annealing temperature of NDs (>1700 C) leads to an increase in the degree of carbon ordering [62,7,24]. The specific surface area (SSA) obtained by gas sorption (N2) ranges between 400 and 600 m2 g 1 for ND-derived CNOs obtained at temperatures between 1300 and 1800 C [63,64].
Raman spectroscopy provides information on the chemical structure of CNs. Fig. 3a thoroughly demonstrates the structural changes of NDs from growth at annealing temperatures in the range of 1200 and 2000 C [48]. The Raman spectrum of NDs shows two features at 1350 and 1600 cm 1 corresponding to the disorder-induced D band and G band for graphitic carbon in a twodimensional hexagonal lattice and shows a feature at 2700 cm 1 that corresponds to the highly dispersive secondorder harmonic 2D band. The G band is characteristic of sp2-hybridized carbon and related to the E2g vibration and can be used to explain the degree of graphitization [65]. The D band corresponds to defects and depends on the amount of disorder in the structure [66]. Increasing the annealing temperature leads to a growth in
diffractograms of ND and CNOs synthesized at different temperatures in an argon ciety of Chemistry and Elsevier.
sharpness of the D and G bands and a decrease of the secondary amorphous carbon signal [67]. The ratio of the D band intensity to the G band intensity (ID/IG) indicates the number of defects on the graphitic layers and the degree of crystalline perfection. The intensity ratio ID/IG decreases with an increase of the annealing temperature, which is connected with the degree of graphitization and growth in the texture ordering (from 2.1 for 1300 C to 1.3 for 1800 C) [63]. X-ray powder diffraction (XRD) has demonstrated the transformation of ND particles with sp3-hybridized carbon into spherical CNOs and then into polyhedral onions with sp2 graphitic carbon [68,24]. Fig. 3b shows the structural changes during a heat treatment of the ND particles at different temperatures. The strongest peak corresponds to the (1 1 1) peak of the diamond structure in the XRD diffractogram, and the weaker peaks corresponds to diamond peaks ((2 2 0), (3 1 1), (4 0 0)) and small quantities of sp2-hybridized carbon (0 0 2). When the annealing temperature of the NDs is increased, a decrease in the intensity of the (1 1 1), (2 2 0), (3 1 1) diamond peaks and an increase in the intensity of the (0 0 2) (0 0 4), (1 1 0) graphite peaks are observed. The growth of graphitic carbon peaks with some amount of diamond peaks was observed at the temperatures up to 1700 C. At the final annealing temperature up to 2000 C, no diamond peaks and only clear-cut graphitic peaks were observed [68,19]. These variations of the physical properties of the CNOs derived from NDs are strongly connected with further chemical properties of the CNOs.

sections.heading: 3. Structural modification of CNOs via physical methods
sections.text:
The use of nanomaterials in many areas requires controlling their structural and physicochemical properties at the micro- and macroscopic level. Structural modification of the multi-layered, spherical CNO particles can be mainly affected by heat treatment under different atmospheres [68], and electron beam irradiation methods [69]. The structural properties of CNs affect their electronic properties, and in this respect, the ability to control their structural transformations is relevant to receive suitable functional properties. One of the most remarkable properties of CNOs is selfcompression when they are exposed to electron or ion irradiation at high temperatures [70,69,71,72,73]. The distance between the graphitic shells is smaller than the corresponding distance in graphite (0.335 nm) and can reach values as low as that present in diamond (diamond planes are separated by a distance of 0.206 nm). The self-compression process of CNs leads to higher organization of the graphitic shells. Banhart et al. [69] described the transformation of spherical CNOs with a diameter of approximately 10–20 nm to diamond by electron beam irradiation at high temperatures ( 700 C). The distance between lattice planes decreased from the outside of the structure to the inside from 0.31 nm in CNOs to approximately 0.22 nm, corresponding to the compression of the particle centre [72]. The increasing compression between lattice planes to the particle centre can be explained by an increasing density of cross-links per unit area of the layers. The transformation of spherical CNOs to NDs was also observed by irradiating graphitic carbon soot with Ne+ ions of 3-MeV energy [73]. The mechanism of the self-compression of CNOs and their transformation to diamond were studied in situ using electron energy loss spectroscopy at 700–1100 C in a 1.25-MeV energy electron microscope [71]. The spectra exhibited increasing electron density and a gradual transition of the graphite-like sp2-hybridized carbon atoms in carbon onions to diamond-like sp3-hybridized carbon during the self-compression of CNOs.
Carbon nano-onions were also formed at different temperatures (1650 and 1750 C) in a He atmosphere, and such nanostructures were additionally annealed in different atmospheres (air, N2, and
CO2) [52,74]. As a consequence of these experiments, the CNO nanostructures showed compressed distances between graphene layers in the range of 0.32 and 0.29 nm (Fig. 4a, b). Annealing of CNOs under a CO2 atmosphere caused damage and disruption to their graphene sheet structure [74]. In addition to the spherical CNO structures formed during the annealing process, some elliptical and polyhedral nanoparticles were also formed.
The carbonization of carbohydrates (glucose or starch) in the presence of CNOs changed their structural properties and allowed for the preparation of three-dimensional porous structures [75]. Carbonization of carbohydrates is frequently reported as a cheap, economical and easy way to prepare carbon spheres with a high number of functional groups [76]. Another advantage of using these molecules in the annealing process is their low carbonization temperature of approximately 400 C. CNOs were formed by annealing 5-nm ND powder at 1650 C in a low-pressure He atmosphere. Further low-temperature annealing, defined as a post-modification process, in air at 450 C in the presence of carbohydrates (glucose or starch) was performed. HRTEM studies show (Fig. 4c, d) that the post-modification process occurring during the low-temperature annealing process in air appears to lead to CNO compression, graphitization and polygonization (faceting structure). After postmodification, the carbon nano-onions are in a compressed state and the spacing between the CNO layers range from 0.32 nm to 0.27 nm. TEM, SEM and TGA studies show the graphitization of the CNO nanostructures, and their transformation during that process shows correlation between the mass of the carbohydrates in the starting material and the textural changes of the CNOs.

sections.heading: 4. Doping of CNOs with metals and heteroatoms
4.1. Doping of CNOs with metals
sections.text:
Carbon-encapsulated metal nanoparticles have garnered significant interest because of their unique physicochemical properties [77] and wide spectrum of clinical [78] and electrochemical [79] applications. Various methods have been used for the synthesis of encapsulated metal nanoparticles inside onion-like nanostructures, such as arc-discharge methods [80,81] electron beam irradiation [82,83,23], chemical vapour deposition (CVD) [84,85] and pulsed plasma in liquid [86].
A transformation of an amorphous carbon film in the presence of Al nanoparticles into giant onion-like structures has been reported [83]. The process was performed at the room temperature under ion-beam irradiation (200 kV). The aluminium nanoparticles acted as a nucleation centres and were surrounded by ca. 10–54 graphitic shells (approx. 4–38 nm in size). The mechanism of the formation of these nanostructures can be represented in a threestage process: (1) the formation of an Al nucleus and the first layer of the multi-layered fullerenes, (2) the growth of fullerene’s and irregular ellipsoidal shells with hollow interiors, and (3) the elimination of the hollow interior and changing of the ellipsoidal shells to quasi-spheroidal shells. Intercalation with another type of nanoparticles, such as Au, Sn, Pb, Ni, Fe or Co, has also been reported [89,23,82]. The formation of spherical onion-like particles with different metal cores and different diameters using temperatures up to 1400 C was observed (Fig. 5a, b). Raman analyses of these nanostructures showed well-organized graphitic structures and highly disordered carbon shells, which allowed for their easy functionalisation. Thermal gravimetric analysis of the onion-like carbon-encapsulated Co, Ni and Fe nanoparticles showed their high thermal stability under thermal treatment and an oxidation process. These nanoparticles exhibited ferromagnetic properties.
The encapsulation of metal oxide in graphitic shells was also performed. Encapsulation of Co3O4 or NiO was obtained by an
arc-discharge method and by annealing at 300 or 500 C for 2 h in air. A new type of nanocapsules with a spherical Co3O4 or NiO core and diameters between ca. 10 and 30 nm with onion-like carbon nanoparticles with shell thicknesses of approximately 1.5 nm were obtained [80,81].
Despite the ability of the onion-like structures to incorporation the metal in their interior, it is also possible to modify their surface in a post-modification process leading to the adsorption of metal nanoparticles on the CNO surface (Fig. 5c–f). Doping of onion-like structures with Pt, Pd and Ni nanoparticles by arc-discharge in aqueous solution [87] and electron beam irradiation [90] was performed. Platinum nanoparticles with diameters of 5 nm were obtained from the reduction of [PtCl6]2 during the arc-discharge method in solution between two pristine graphite electrodes [87]. The darkest area in the HRTEM images correspond to Pt nanoparticles with diameters of 3–8 nm (Fig. 5e, f). In this process the spherical CNOs with diameters in the range between 5 and 60 nm were formed. The Pt/CNO hybrid is an attractive material for industrial catalysis. Palladium clusters were obtained via the reduction of H2PdCl4 and amorphous carbon with electron irradiation [90]. These clusters in the carbon matrix with diameters of 2– 3 nm represent five-, six- or seven layered structures. The CNO shells had some defects. The distances between the layers in the carbon onion with Pd clusters (0.38–0.44 nm) were larger than ordinary graphitic carbon (0.334 nm). Other reactions have also been reported, such as modification with metal nanoparticles Pt [87,91,92], Mo2C [39], and Pd [93].

sections.heading: 4.2. Doping of CNOs with heteroatoms
sections.text:
Metal-free carbon materials doped with heteroatoms, such as nitrogen, boron, sulphur, and/or phosphorus have been an effective method to change their physical and chemical properties. Borondoped onion-like carbon was obtained by an in situ method during electron irradiation of a graphitic material in TEM [94]. A boronrich graphitic material was synthesized via the chemical vapour deposition of BCl3 and C6H6. During this process, many products were produced: an onion-like structure (over 20 graphitic layers), single-layer fullerenes, small nested fullerenes (4–7 layers) and ellipsoid-like nested nanostructures (6–8 layers). The ratio of B to C was varied from 0.02 to 0.10 and was measured by electron energy loss spectroscopy. Lin and coworkers synthesized borondoped onion-like carbon via the thermal annealing of ND using boric acid as boron precursor [95,96,97]. In this work, 8, 15, and 25 wt% concentrations of boric acid were mixed with NDs, and further annealing at 1500 C in an argon atmosphere was performed. From this procedure, materials with different concentrations of substituted boron were obtained (1.5–5 wt%). The boron doping of the carbon nanostructure led to a slight decrease of the interlayer spacing with increasing boron content. XPS spectroscopy confirmed the presence of a boron atom cluster ( 186.5 eV), B4C ( 187.6 eV), a substitutional boron species BC3 ( 188.8 eV), BC2O ( 190.1 eV), B-N ( 191.1 eV) and a B2O3-related species (>192.0 eV). Raman data showed more structural defects for the boron-doped CNs compared to undoped CNOs. These nanostructures showed catalytic properties towards N2H4. The boron-doped catalysts were shown to have good stability under recycling tests in nitrobenzene reduction. In another work, the relationship between the electronic properties and the catalytic performance of the boron-doped onion-like carbon obtained by the thermal annealing of a mixture of boron acid and ND was investigated [95]. Different annealing temperatures (1500; 1800; 2100 and 2400 C) and concentrations of boric acid (5, 10 and 20 wt%) were used. It was observed that the skeletal density increased with an increasing boron content. The highest boron content led to a lower
conductivity and more disordered fullerene-like layered structures.
A novel structure, named aza-fullerene, consisting of crosslinked nano-onions of carbon nitride (structural formula C60-2nN2n) in the solid phase was reported [98]. These structures were obtained by magnetron sputtering of a carbon-graphite target in Ar and 10% N2 atmosphere (0.4 Pa) at temperatures between 200 and 450 C. The applied ion energy was 28 eV, and the ion flux was 0.075 mA cm 2. According to electron microscopy and energy loss spectroscopy, C48N12 aza-fullerene composites formed with core shells containing up to 20 wt% nitrogen. The onion-like shells (7–10 shells with diameters up to 7 nm) were formed as a solid film through magnetron sputter deposition. The substitution of nitrogen to onion-like shells led to a decrease in the energy barrier to form graphitic pentagons and contributed to the growth of fullerene-like phases. This material was discovered to be a highly elastic material combined with significant hardness. The hardness of C48N12 was 7 GPa, and Young’s modulus was 37 GPa according to the Oliver and Pharr model. In this respect, C48N12 aza-fullerene is a promising candidate for wear-protective applications, for example, as a protective top coating on magnetic heads and hard disks.
Another method of synthesis for carbon onion-like structures with a high content of nitrogen atoms was investigated using pyridine [99]. Nitrogen-doped onion-like carbon (or ‘‘pyridinic carbon”) was obtained using pyrolysis in the gas phase during the polymerization and polycondensation reactions of pyridine molecules. Nitrogen-doped CNs were also obtained by an arc discharge method in the liquid phase with different ammonia concentrations (1 or 5 mol L 1) [100]. According to TEM measurements, nanoparticles with 5–12 graphitic shells with more defective outermost shells and less defective innermost shells were synthesized. XPS investigations revealed that increasing the ammonia concentration led to an increase of the degree of nitrogen doping to 1.7 at.%. These measurements also confirmed the presence of pyridinic-, pyrrolic-, quaternary- and oxidized-nitrogen functionalities.

sections.heading: 4.3. Doping of CNOs with metals and heteroatoms
sections.text:
Recently, the combination of both processes, encapsulating a metal in the carbon onion core and the nitrogen-doping of carbon onions, was pursued due to their unique properties and their practical application [101–104]. The CNO structures were synthesized by a heat treatment of carbon black in the presence of hexamethylene diamine as a carbon–nitrogen precursor and Co or Fe metals [101,105,106]. In this work, metal salts, Co(NO3)2 H2O and FeCl3 in mass ratio of 1:3, as the Co, Fe and binary CoFe source were applied. The syntheses were carried out using a vacuum-dried procedure at 900 C in a nitrogen atmosphere. Cobalt-based nanoparticles exhibited higher a degree of graphitization, which was confirmed by a much sharper carbon (0 0 2) peak in XRD analysis. The BET surface area analysis showed that the highest value of 560 m2 g 1 was achieved for the CoAN-onion-like carbon nanostructures. The binary CoFe nanostructures exhibited the highest catalytic activity. The activity increased with an increase of the metal content from 0.5 to 3 wt%.
Hexamethylene diamine (HDA), FeCl3 and Co(NO3)2 6H2O were used as nitrogen and transition metal precursors [104]. Nitrogendoped onion-like structures were synthesized by the pyrolysis of HDA-Me (Me: Co and Fe) complexes at 900 C in a nitrogen atmosphere, and from this reaction, N-Me-C materials were obtained. The formation of spherical onion-like structures with outer diameters with sizes from 2 to 5 nm and a distance between graphitic layers of 0.28 nm was observed according to TEM measurements. The graphitic layers formed structures with irregular curvature with some defects at the edges of the carbon fragments. Similar derivatives have also been prepared in the presence of Pt [107].
Nitrogen-doped carbon-onion-encapsulated metals were synthesized by the pyrolysis of Ni2Fe(CN)6 at 600 C in a nitrogen atmosphere [103]. The spherical nanoparticles with encapsulated metals (FeNi3 or FeCo) with an average diameter of approximately 30 and 66 nm with FeNi3 and FeCo cores, respectively, were observed. The Raman spectra showed a high degree of graphitization of these nanostructures.
Nickel/nitrogen-doped carbon nano-onions (Ni/N-CNOs) were synthesized by an arc-discharge method using a N2 atmosphere as the N-atom source [102]. In this process, spherical nanoparticles with diameters of 10–80 nm were obtained, which was confirmed by TEM investigations. XPS data showed 1.24 at.% N content in Ni/ N-CNO nanocapsules. Raman studies indicated a large number of lattice defects and imperfections in their shells. Nickel/nitrogendoped carbon onions are hopeful candidates as electromagnetic wave absorbers with high environmental stability and comparatively low cost.

sections.heading: 5. Covalent and non-covalent functionalisation of CNOs
sections.text:
After the discovery of CNOs, chemical modification of their surfaces were studied intensively. It is well known that the reactivity of fullerene-like structures decreases with an increase in their size due to a decrease in the curvature (and the associated strain) of the surface [108]. Many CNs show high chemical resistances. Similarly, CNOs have poor solubility in organic and inorganic solvents because of aggregation, which is a result of strong intermolecular interactions such as the van der Waals forces [109]. Their edges with highly curved surfaces display relatively high chemical reactivity as compared to other graphitic nanostructures. The ability to functionalise the spherical ‘‘small” CNO surfaces is also connected with the presence of defects in the carbon network as well as the presence of carbon atoms with sp3 hybridization on the surface of the nanoparticles [110]. Both covalent and non-covalent
Scheme 1. Covalent functionalisation pathways for CNOs [109]. Reprinte
reactions can occur on CNOs to attach multiple groups on their surfaces to improve their solubility and to change their physicochemical properties. Among them is oxidation [111–114] 1,3-dipolar cycloaddition [115,4], amidation [116], [2+1] cycloaddition [117], nucleophilic substitution [118], diazonium addition [119], reduction and alkylation [118] and radical polymerization [120] (Scheme 1).
The oxidation reaction, in many cases, is used as the first stage for further functionalisation of CNs. Therefore, it is one of the most widely used reactions leading to increased solubility of the carbon nanoparticles in aqueous solutions. Activation of the CNO surfaces has been achieved by chemical oxidation with inorganic acids [111–113] chemical activation with potassium peroxide [121] and covalent modification with acid derivatives [122]. Chemical oxidation enables the formation of oxygen-containing functional groups on the surface of the CNs, such as aldehydes, ketones, esters, alcohols, and carboxylic acids, and forms defects in their graphitic structures [123,124]. When carbon materials are oxidized or reduced with extremely aggressive agents, their hydrophilicity increases because of an increase in the concentration and distribution of oxygen atoms on the carbon nanostructures. On the other hand, this process causes damage and structural changes on the carbon surfaces by disrupting their graphene sheet structure and with a simultaneous loss of the p-conjugated system on the graphene layers. Therefore, after chemical activation, especially with acids, some inorganic ions, e.g., sulphide or nitride, are adsorbed on the carbon surface, which affects the chemical properties of the nanostructures [124].
To retain the ‘‘conductive” structure of CNOs, mild oxidative conditions have been performed, such as dilute nitric acid or an ozonolysis process [112,52,114]. Oxidation of CNOs through ozonolysis does not require the use of aggressive oxidants and is a simple method leading to surface modification of the CN. The process does not result in any damage to the structure of the CNO external graphene layer [114]. For both samples, oxidized in
d with permission from Ref. [109]. Copyright 2017 Beilstein-Institut.
presence of dilute nitric acid or ozone, the main C 1s peak in XPS studies was asymmetric, which is characteristic of a conducting form of carbon (e.g., graphite) [125]. The presence of carbon atoms bound to CAO, ACAOACA, ACOOH or C@O was also detected. The functionalised CNOs are very well dispersible in many polar solvents (water, methanol and tetrahydrofuran).
It was already highlighted that the reactivity of CNOs depends on their size and strain. Increasing the size of these nanostructures results in a decrease in their reactivity [29]. Therefore, most of the reactions are carried out by covalent functionalisation with ‘‘small” CNOs, i.e., those derived from NDs in an annealing process. The first of these reactions was published in 2003 describing the functionalisation of CNOs in the presence of an amino acid and paraformaldehyde [115]. Three years later, the first report was published concerning the improvement of the solubility of carbon nanoparticles in different organic and inorganic solvents [28]. In this article, three types of reactions were presented: PEGylation, amidation and 1,3-dipolar cycloaddition. First, the oxidized CNOs were reacted with diamine-terminated oligomeric poly(ethylene glycol) at 140 C for 19 days. Using the same oxidized CNOs and 1-octadecylamine (ODA), ODA-functionalised CNOs were prepared. The reaction was carried out using both solid-state and microwave reactions. The first one applied a heating process at 170 C in a sealed glass ampoule, and the second one concerned a reaction in a microwave reactor at 120 C in a dimethylformamide solution. A third modification was based on a reaction with N-ethylglycine and dodecanal [28]. The three products were soluble in various polar solvents.
Later, in 2007, the direct fluorination of CNOs at three different temperatures was described [126]. The CNOs were placed in a reactor and heated to a selected temperature of 350, 410, or 480 C and kept for 2–3 h. After heating for the selected time, flu-
Scheme 2. (a) Synthesis of BODA-CNO – copolymer [120]; (b) Cyclopropanation of CN Chemical Society.
orine and hydrogen gases were introduced separately at a controlled 3:1 flow rate ratio for 6 h. The authors suggested that the predominantly covalent bonding of fluorine to carbon cages occurred when the highest temperature was used. The fluorinated CNOs have improved solubility in organic solvents, such as alcohols and dimethylformamide, as compared to the pristine CNO and can be used for further modification. A different fluorination reaction was proposed by Kuznetsov et al. [127]. The fluorinated CNOs were obtained from a reaction with a lithium monosucrate derivative. The product was soluble in water and dimethylformamide, and the physicochemical characteristics showed that this product may be biocompatible and useful in mechanically reinforced composites. Another type of fluoro-derivative was obtained by the radical addition of a conjugated polymer to the CNs [120]. Carbon nano-onions were sonicated with 4,40-(perfluoropropane2,2-diyl)bis(1,2-bis(phenylethynyl)benzene) (BODA 6F Ph) in Nmethyl-2-pyrrolidinone (NMP) and then refluxed for 4 days in a pressure vessel (Scheme 2a). The obtained product was useful for the fabrication of novel CNO composites.
The next work involved the functionalisation of CNOs with OH and Br groups using a [2+1] cycloaddition reaction [117]. The functionalised CNOs had better solubility in organic solvents. Therefore, the hydroxyl-functionalised CNOs showed fluorescence in water. These derivatives were also used for further reactions, such as in situ polymerizations of poly(e-caprolactone) and polystyrene. The polymer-functionalised CNOs had good dispersibility in common organic solvents [117]. Another type of [2+1] addition reaction, called Bingel-Hirsch cyclopropanation, and a free-radical addition have been reported by Palkar et al. [29]. Pristine CNOs (undoped and unmodified) of different sizes were dispersed in anhydrous 1,2-dichlorobenzene (ODCB), and the reaction was carried in the presence of dodecylmalonate, carbon tetrabromide
O [29]. Reprinted with permission from Refs. [120,125]. Copyright 2017 American
(CBr4) and 1,8-diazabicyclo[5.4.0]undec-7-ene (DBU) (Scheme 2b). Next, to obtain the phenylated-CNO derivatives, benzoyl peroxide was used. Phenylated CNOs obtained from the free-radical-addition reaction were used for a sulphonation reaction in oleum, and further the treatment with NaOH was applied. The residual product was highly dispersible in water and ethanol.
A porphyrin-CNO derivative was obtained using diazonium compounds and zinc monoazaporphyrin [119]. The pristine CNOs were dispersed in dimethylformamide, and then, an aniline derivative and isoamyl nitrite were added. The mixture was stirred overnight at 60 C. A mild and selective deprotection reaction of carbamates with tetra-n-butylammonium fluoride, proposed by Campidelli et al. [128], was used in this procedure. The obtained product was applied for further functionalisation with different compounds such as metal complexes [119].
Obtaining well-soluble CNOs in organic solvent is a very difficult task. Echegoyen and coworkers reported the reduction of CNOs using a Na–K alloy and nucleophilic substitution using 1-bromohexadecane [118]. The product showed good dispersity in many solvents, such as dichloromethane, toluene, N-methyl-2-pyrrolidone, 1,2-dimethoxyethane, tetrahydrofuran and dimethylacetamide. The same group reported the functionalisation of CNOs by ferrocene derivatives in a two-step reaction [4] in the presence of an amino acid, paraformaldehyde and ferrocene carboxylic acid. The electrochemical and photophysical studies of the ferrocenederivatives showed the existence of interactions between the ferrocene moieties and the CNO cages.
Supramolecular solubilization of the modified CNOs by the formation of inclusion complexes has also been described in the literature [27]. The oxidized CNOs (by a sulphuric acid/nitric acid mixture) were sonicated in aqueous solution and stirred with N-Ethyl-N0-(3-dimethylaminopropyl)carbodiimide hydrochloride, N-Hydroxysuccinimide and aminated b-cyclodextrin. From this reaction, cyclodextrin-modified CNOs were obtained, which were further applied as hosts for inclusion complexes with polymerferrocene groups as guests.
The next very interesting modification of CNOs was proposed by Giordani et al. [129], which was based on the formation of carbon nanoparticle derivatives with near-infrared fluorescent properties. CNOs were subsequently modified with 4-aminobenzoic acid in the presence of an isoamylnitrite catalyst, activated esters and boron difluoride azadipyrromethene derivatives. From this reaction, carbon-based nanomaterials consisting of boron difluoride azadipyrromethene fluorophores covalently attached to CNOs were obtained with very interesting biological application. Similar biological properties were shown for the next CNO-derivatives synthesized in the same group (Silvia Giordani et al. [130]). In that article, fluoro-CNOderivativeswere obtained in aN2 atmosphere using oxidized-CNOs, dimethylaminopyridine, and fluoresceinamine in the
Scheme 3. Procedure for the synthesis of dual-functionalized CNOs. Synthetic procedur PEG4) by amide coupling and with the fluorescein unit (FITC-PEG 6) by copper catalyse [131]. Copyright 2017 John Wiley and Sons.
presence of activators (N-Ethyl-N0-(3-dimethylaminopropyl)carbodiimide hydrochloride and N-hydroxysuccinimide). The modification of the CNOs was confirmed by several experimental methods, mainly thermogravimetric and spectroscopic (FTIR and Raman) analyses, that showed high fluorescence of the CNOs and their dispersability in water. The synthesis of the fluorescent multifunctional CNOs was performed followed the procedure presented in Scheme 3 [131]. The pristine CNOs were subjected to a series of reactions with diazonium salts to covalently functionalise these CNOs with benzoic acid groups and phenylacetylene moieties, which then underwent CuAAC ligation to attach the fluorescein unit (FITC-PEG6) on the surface of the CNOs. This multi-functionalised CNOderivativemay be a promising tool for bioimaging applications.
This summary presented only a few reactions, which, in the opinion of the authors, are very important for further applications. Therefore, these reactions significantly changed the physicochemical properties of the carbon nanostructures, which will allow for their use in many areas, mainly electronics, electrochemistry and medicine. We will briefly described these applications in the next paragraph.

sections.heading: 6. Potential applications of CNOs
sections.text:
Due to the unique physicochemical properties of CNOs, these nanostructures are used in many areas, mainly in electronics [132–134], in optical limiting [135], in catalysis [136,137], in energy conversion and storage [138], in Li-ion electrochemicalenergy-storage devices [139,140], as hyperlubricants [141–143], for sensors [144,145] and for biological and environmental applications [109,146,129,148,149]. One of the most interesting physical properties of CNOs is their conductivity. CNOs formed from nanodiamond particles at high temperatures ( 1800 C) have showed the best performance in terms of conductivity. We analysed the electronic conductance of a single CNO structure functionalised with sulphide-terminated chains in order to trap molecules in metal-molecule-metal junctions [132]. Our studies showed that electron conduction through the junctions occurs by a superexchange mechanism, and the conductance of the CNOs is approximately 71.8 lS, which is close to metallic behaviour [150].
The next very interesting application of CNOs is their catalytic performance. Pristine and oxidized CNOs were applied for oxidative dehydrogenation of ethylbenzene to styrene [136], [137]. Keller et al. published a study showing the potential of CNOs as catalysts for this reaction with high conversion levels (up to 92%). The catalytic properties were compared to industrial K–Fe catalysts and other carbon materials. From these studies, the authors concluded that the catalytic activities depend mainly on the high surface area of CNOs and their functionalities.
e for the covalent functionalization of CNO derivative with the folic acid unit (FAd azide–alkyne Huisgen cycloaddition [131]. Reprinted with permission from Ref.
More recently, heteroatom doping of carbon nanomaterials has been shown to be a promising approach for the development of carbon-based electrocatalysts. Doping carbon materials with heteroatoms, such as nitrogen, boron, sulphur, and/or phosphorus, has been an effective method to change the electronic structure, surface chemistry and, in consequence, the catalytic properties. Doping of carbon materials with donors or acceptors can improve the electronic performance of CNs. Incorporating boron atoms into the carbon matrix has led to the formation of an electron-deficient p-type (hole) nanostructure [151]. Incorporation of phosphorus, sulphur and nitrogen atoms leads to the formation of electronabundant n-type nanostructures (free electrons). Boron-doped materials with low contents of B ( 2 wt%) in comparison to other reported heteroatom-doped carbon materials show better physicochemical characteristics and can be applied in semiconductors, quantum dots, supercapacitors and batteries [97]. Due to the high cost of platinum catalysts for the oxygen reduction reaction (ORR) in fuel cell applications, looking for a non-platinum group metal catalyst is still necessary. Doping CNOs with electron-deficient boron leads to good catalytic activity of this material, and this material was used for the oxygen electrode reaction in sodiumoxygen (Na-O2) batteries. Properties of cathode materials, such as specific surface area, morphology, porosity and surface chemistry, play a significant role in the charging behaviour and the cycling performance of Na-O2 batteries [152–154]. Na-O2 batteries with B-doped CNO electrodes exhibited higher charging potentials, discharge capacities and capacity retention capabilities than undoped CNOs. Boron-doped CNOs also exhibited excellent electrocatalytic efficiencies, higher tolerances for methanol, higher activities, higher stabilities and lower costs in comparison with Pt and can be a promising candidate for cost-effective ORR [155–157].
The influence of heteroatoms on the catalytic activity of carbons was interpreted in terms of semiconductor properties. Doping N atoms into the graphite lattice lowers the band gap, leading to higher electron mobility and enhanced catalytic activity in electron-transfer reactions. N-doped onion-like carbon materials were investigated as efficient oxygen electrodes for rechargeable longlife lithium-oxygen (Li–O2) batteries [158]. These derivatives with large specific surface areas were used as electrocatalysts and improved Li–O2 battery performances (high efficiency, high specific capacity, good rate performance and excellent cycle stability). N-doped onion-like carbon materials were also applied as catalysts for catalytic ORR in photon-exchange-membrane fuel cells [100]. Carbon nano-onions with metal oxide cores, such as Co3O4 [80] and NiO [81], are great candidates as anode materials for lithium ion batteries due to their improved electrochemical and cyclic performance, high reversible capacity, safety [80], excellent discharge capacity and high rate charge-discharge capability [81]. Onion-like structures with FeNi3 and FeCo cores have exhibited excellent catalytic activities with outstanding conversion efficiencies ( 8.9%). These nanostructures have showed excellent chemical stability, superior catalytic activities towards triiodide reduction, high structural stability in iodine-containing medium and low charge-transfer resistance between electrode surfaces and electrolytes. These results make them promising catalysts in comparison to Pt catalysts and highly efficient and stable counter electrodes for dye-sensitized solar cells.
The spherical structure of CNOs also allows for use in tribological studies [34,142,141]. These studies have been conducted mainly with ‘‘small” CNO structures. Hirata et al. examined ballon-disc-type friction testing of the tribological properties of CNOs. Their studies showed that CNOs exhibited a low, stable friction coefficient (<0.1) both in air and in vacuum at room temperature, which was lower than graphite powder [141]. Both experimental and computational investigations clearly showed that CNOs used as lubricant additives led to a strong reduction of friction and wear,
even at low temperatures, due to rolling and sliding processes inside the contact area [143].
The high surface areas of CNOs play a main role in many areas of their potential uses. Oxidized CNOs were used as platforms for the adsorption of heavy metal ions [148]. Oxidized CNOs possessed 10- fold higher sorption capacity than C60 for contaminants including Pb2+, Cu2+, Cd2+, Ni2+, and Zn2+ in a pH range from 5 to 9, which is consistent with environmentally relevant conditions.
Drug targeting applications frequently require developed surface areas and nontoxicity of nanoparticles. Hydrophilic CNO composites were successfully used for flavonoid incorporation [159]. The non-covalent functionalisation of poly(4-vinylpyridine-costyrene) or poly(ethylene) glycol/polysorbate 20 with CNOs was reported, which were facile ways to create a matrix for further functionalisation with thiol derivatives. During these functionalisations, composites were created that are promising systems for biosensing and drug targeting applications. Composites containing CNOs and poly(diallyldimethylammonium chloride) (CNO/PDDA) were applied as electrodes in the electrochemical detection of dopamine [145]. The results showed good selectivity and sensitivity for dopamine analysis with the determination of dopamine in a range between 5 10 5 and 4 10 3 mol L 1 in the presence of ascorbic and uric acids. The CNO/PDDA electrodes can also be used for the simultaneous determination of all three molecules in buffered solution.
Investigations concerning cytotoxicity and resulting biological and medical applications of CNOs are also very promising. Investigations with normal cells, using a colorimetric assay for measuring the activity of cellular enzymes that reduce the tetrazolium dye (MTT method), confirmed the low toxicity of CNOs. Tests showed good biocompatibility of unmodified CNOs, oxidized CNOs and PEGylated nanostructures over a wide range of concentrations. This study also showed that CNOs can be used as a platform for the immobilization of biomolecules while keeping their bioactivity. Cytotoxic effects have also been studied using onion-like nanostructures with Co, Ni and Fe cores [86]. Cytotoxicity measurements showed that Fe-CNOs and Co-CNOs exhibited high viability of HeLa cancer cells at approximately 95 and 98%, respectively, [160,161]. This showed that these nanoparticles may be applied in magnetic hyperthermia and in cancer therapies with minimum side effects.
The biological activity of well-dispersed CNO/surfactant composites (containing hexadecyltrimethylammonium bromide, sodium dodecyl sulphate, sodium dodecyl benzene sulphonate, 4-(1,1,3,3-tetramethylbutyl)phenyl-polyethylene glycol and polyethylene glycol sorbitan monolaurate) against a strain of Escherichia coli was also assayed [162]. In vitro antimicrobial assays for these composites revealed that only the CNO/hexadecyltrimethylammonium bromide composite decreased cell viability.
Modified CNOs have also been applied as a nontoxic, fluorescent reagent enabling Drosophila melanogaster (fruit flies) [146]. These CNO derivatives allow optical fluorescence microscopy imaging of all stages of the fruit fly life cycle without showing any toxic effects. Analogous studies were performed towards two model organisms: unicellular Escherichia coli and multicellular Caenorhabditis elegans [147]. The in vivo studies showed that CNOs serve as highly fluorescent bioimaging agents for both organismswithout any toxic effects on the growth of these organisms. These observations opened up new possibilities for using CNO nanostructures in nanotoxicology research and biomedical applications including drug delivery. Giordani et al. have used fluorophores-functionalised CNOs in comparative toxicological in vitro and in vivo studies [129,149]. These observations opened up new possibilities for using CNO nanostructures in nanotoxicology research and biomedical applications including drug delivery. The cytotoxicity and immunomodulatory properties of the CNO derivatives were compared with similarly
functionalised CNTs (Fig. 6, Panel 1) [163]. They demonstrated cellular imaging of HeLa Kyoto [129] andMCF-7 cells [149]. The highly fluorescent boron dipyrromethene (BODIPY-CNOs) dyes attached to the CNO surface gave the in vitro probe high-resolution imaging of MCF-7 human breast cancer cells [149]. The in vivo imaging of BODIPY-CNOs in zebrafish larvae was also performed [164]. Fig. 6 (Panel 2) illustrates the in vivo distribution of BODIPY-CNOs in the zebrafish developed at complete organogenesis and exposed to 100 lg mL 1 mass concentration of the BODIPY-CNO nanomaterial. BODIPY-CNOs were able to enter the circulatory system and accumulate in different areas of the whole zebrafish. Due to their efficient cellular uptake, weak inflammatory potential, and low cytotoxicity of the fluorophores-functionalised CNOs, these fluorescent derivatives are promising materials for biomedical applications.
Another condition necessary for the use of nanoparticles in biosensors is the ability to interact or form chemical bonds with biological compounds without a decrease of biological activity. Constructing biosensors with immobilized oxidized CNOs was based on avidin-biotin interactions [144]. Surface plasmon resonance spectroscopy was used to detect self-assembled organic monolayers and to monitor biomolecular interactions. The avidin-biotin biosensor was formed ‘‘layer-by-layer” with oxidized-CNOs as one of the layers. Different configurations of biosensor formation were checked to select the system with greatest sensitivity of avidin determination. From the analysis of the obtained data, it was found that the sequence of immobilizing particular layers and the chemical characteristics and sizes of the applied particles or chemical compounds were able to cause significant surface changes. A biosensor containing CNOs as one of the layers changed the structural properties of the surface, causing reinforcement of the analytical signal for avidin. The conducted research showed that CNOs can be successfully used as platforms for immobilizing molecules, as they retain the bioactivity of the latter and allow for the reinforcement of the measured signal, increasing the sensitivity of the applied method.

sections.heading: 6.1. Electrochemical properties of CNOs and their composites as charge collectors
sections.text:
Currently, some of the most effective and practical technologies used in electrochemical energy converters include fuel cells, bat-
teries and electrochemical capacitors [165,166]. The discovery of nanostructured forms of carbon had a dramatic impact on the design and preparation of new electrode materials. The unique combination of the very favourable mechanical properties of these CNs with similarly convenient chemical and physical properties, namely, relatively high surface-to-volume ratio, reasonably high conductivity, excellent corrosion resistance, high thermal stability, controlled size distribution, satisfactory compatibility in composite materials and cost effectiveness, make these very attractive as capacitor materials [167,168].
Carbon nanostructures, such as CNOs and CNTs, defined as exohedral capacitors have been shown to be ideal materials for the easy penetration of ions on carbon/electrolyte surfaces (Fig. 7) [169]. The closed structures of ND-derived CNOs enable progress of fast processes of charge transfer and their use in organic electrolytes at temperatures as low as 40 C and in ionic liquid electrolytes at 50 C. CNO-based electrochemical capacitors can operate at temperatures between 50 and 100 C over a wide potential window (up to 3.7 V) and at very high charge/discharge rates (up to 200 V s 1) (Fig. 7b) [170].
Non-modified carbon nanostructures have somewhat limited charge accumulation properties [111,48,60]. Thus, the short review below has focused on their chemical derivatives, mainly containing CNO composites, which possess different physicochemical characteristics than non-modified carbon nanostructures. This approach is intended to mainly utilize a combination Faradaic reactions from the redox-capacitive materials with the robustness of carbon structures to produce composites with superior electrochemical properties. In the composite materials, a synergistic effect of both components is observed, creating a material with new, unusual physicochemical properties. During the modification of carbon materials, many parameters, such as the degree of hydration and crystallinity of transition metal oxides, the potential degradation of conducting polymers, and the decrease of the surface area of the composites, have to be taken into consideration for the preparation of optimal composite electrodes for electrochemical capacitors and pseudocapacitors [173–176]. The improvement of capacity properties ofmaterials containingCNOswas achievedby the following modifications: (i) preparation of CNO/polyelectrolyte composites [177]; (ii) preparation of CNO/conducting polymer composites [122,178–181]; and (iii) preparation of composites containing CNOs and hydroxides/oxides of transition metals [182–184].
4-ABAC – 4-aminobenzoic acid; Chit – chitosan; oz-CNOs – the ozone treatment of CNOs; ox-CNOs – CNOs oxidized in 3 M HNO3; PANI – polyaniline; PEDOT:PSS – poly(3,4-ethylenedioxythiophene):poly(styrenesulfonate); PDDA – poly(diallyldimethylammonium chloride); Ppy – polypyrrole; SDS – sodium dodecyl sulfate. a2 mg of CNOs or the CNO composites in a solution containing conductive carbon paint and ethanol in 1: 6 (v/v); conductive carbon paint – a dispersion of colloidal graphite (20% solids) in isopropyl alcohol, at 5 V s 1, 1 M KOH. bThe electrochemical oxidation of CNOs was achieved by sweeping the potential from 1 V to 2 V in 1 M H2SO4, and faradaic currents recorded during electrochemical oxidation (5 cycles). Prior to electrochemical treatment, the electrolyte was purged with oxygen for 30 min. Supporting electrolytes were used: c0.1 M HClO4; d0.1 M Na2SO4; gTBAClO4; hLiClO4. iChemical polymerization of Ppy. jElectrochemical polymerization of Ppy or PANI. The sweep rate was 50 mV/s.
Although the created composites display very promising properties for capacitors, the number of publications dealing with CNO functionalisation for those uses is still very low. The current research carried out by the author of this review indicates that CNOs can be used for the synthesis of new composites with high specific capacitance values (Table 2). The advantage of using CNOs (ones with diameters of 5–6 nm), in comparison with larger CNs [185], is that they easily disperse in water solutions as part of the polymerization process. This ensures high homogeneity of the obtained composite and their porous structure. The composite structure mainly depends on the type of starting materials, the type of synthesis (chemical or electrochemical) and the mass ratio of the applied components (Fig. 8). The composites show high mechanical and electrochemical stability in a wide range of potentials and have typical capacitive characteristics.
The studies of the electrochemical properties involve mainly, among others, potential sweep methods that indicate the effective area of the electrode. Cyclic voltammetry (CV) has been predominantly applied in the literature. In the case of studying the electrochemical properties of composites containing CNOs and polyelectrolytes or PEDOT:PSS, the obtained CV curves had a pseudo-rectangular shape in the recorded potential range, characteristic of ideal capacitors. For composites with various mass ratio compositions, it was possible to determine the impact of the components on the electrochemical properties of electrode material. The measurements showed that the layer resistance mainly depended on the polymer component. Increasing the amount of solid polyelectrolyte in the composite led to an increase in dispersion of the material and an increase in porosity, which further resulted in an increase of the capacitance of the obtained films.
Similar dependencies were found for composites containing CNOs and conducting polymers.
Using broadband dielectric spectroscopy, we analysed electric properties of the CNO/polyaniline (CNO/PANI) composites [187,178]. The main findings can be briefly summarized as follows: (i) the huge effective surfaces of CNOs act as multi-layered concentric spherical capacitors and probably induce large capacitance; and (ii) the electric modulus studies indicate that phonon assisted quantum mechanical tunnelling processes operate with conducting PANI and 3D hopping within CNOs and clusters [122].
It was also determined that the specific capacitance values of the materials containing CNOs could be applied in electrochemical capacitors, and these values are presented in Table 1. In each case, combining CNOs with another organic or inorganic materials led to an increase of capacitive current in comparison with the starting components. To obtain the optimum electrode material, many factors had to be taken into consideration when modifying the carbon nanostructures, for example, the rate of hydration reaction and crystallinity of the transition metal oxides, degradation of the conducting polymers and the specific surface area of the composites.
The research involving the synthesis and electrochemical properties of composite materials containing CNOs can be summarized as follows: (i) the easy synthesis of composite materials containing CNOs as well as their ion-exchange and electrochemical properties make them very attractive for electrochemical capacitors; (ii) the good dispersibility of CNOs in organic and inorganic solvents allows for obtaining homogenous composites in combination with both organic and inorganic materials; (iii) two main parameters, the material porosity and the amount of CNOs in the composite mass, affect the composite’s capacitance; (iv) CNOs improve the composite film properties, making them more active for Faradaic reactions, thus, giving them larger specific capacitances and better stabilities than for undoped polymeric or inorganic components; and (v) the presence of CNOs in the film results in an increase of the material’s conductivity.

sections.heading: 7. Conclusions
sections.text:
This comparison showed that CNOs possess unusual physicochemical properties and better nanoporous characteristics than
many carbon-based materials. Although CNOs were discovered almost simultaneously with carbon nanotubes, these equally fascinating molecules have not yet received much attention. It should be emphasized that carbon nano-onions prove to be very unusual and universal, which gives great opportunities for practical application. The areas of potential applications of ‘‘small” carbon nanostructures were shown in this review. It was shown that two of the main areas of CNO applications may be electrochemical capacitors and medical applications.

metadata.abstractText: This article presents a short review of the knowledge concerning carbon nano-onions, also known as onion-like carbon or multi-layered fullerenes. Currently, these nanostructures are some of the most fascinating carbon forms. We can only find approximately 2000 articles under the entry of ‘‘carbon onion” in theWeb of Science. Surprisingly, there have been 40,000 citations since their discovery, and the interest in these nanostructures is still growing. In the last three years, 5000 citations per year have been reported. This means that researchers have noted the unusual nature of these carbon nanostructures. In this article, we review the most important literature reports in this area, which in a condensed way, present these nanostructures, their production methods, their unusual physical and chemical properties and their potential uses. 2017 Elsevier B.V. All rights reserved.
